task_description: help me use ROG strix16 with android phone to watch movies in VR goggle where android phone can fit in

questions.summary: Need to clarify the laptop's role in the setup and confirm the VR goggle type to recommend the correct streaming/display method.

questions.text: What type of VR goggle do you have? Is it a phone-holder style headset (like Google Cardboard, Samsung Gear VR, or generic phone VR holder), or a different type?
questions.context: This determines the entire technical approach - phone-holder VR goggles require apps on the Android phone, while other types may need different solutions. Cannot proceed without knowing this.

questions.text: What role should the ROG Strix 16 laptop play? Do you want to: (A) Stream the laptop's screen to your phone in VR, (B) Use the laptop just to store/serve movie files to the phone, or (C) Watch movies stored on the phone while laptop is unrelated?
questions.context: This defines whether we need screen mirroring software, a media server setup, or just phone-based VR apps. The technical solution differs completely based on this answer.
questions.default_answer: Option A - Stream laptop screen to phone to watch laptop content in VR

questions.text: What type of movie experience do you want? (A) Regular 2D movies on a virtual cinema screen, (B) 3D movies (side-by-side format), or (C) 360° VR videos?
questions.context: Different VR apps specialize in different formats. This determines which apps to recommend and whether you need to convert content formats.
questions.default_answer: Option A - Regular 2D movies on a virtual theater screen

questions.text: Are your laptop and phone on the same WiFi network? If not, are you open to using USB cable connection or setting up WiFi?
questions.context: Wireless streaming (if needed based on Q2) requires same network. Cable connections are possible but limit movement. This affects which solution to recommend.
questions.default_answer: Yes, both devices are on the same WiFi network

questions.text: Where are your movies currently stored? (A) On the laptop's hard drive, (B) Streaming services (Netflix, YouTube, etc.), (C) Already on the phone, or (D) External drive/NAS?
questions.context: This affects the solution complexity - streaming service content may have DRM restrictions, while local files are easier to work with. Helps recommend specific apps and workarounds.
questions.default_answer: Option A - Movies stored on laptop hard drive

answers.Q2: Option A - Stream laptop screen to phone to watch laptop content in VR
answers.Q3: Option A - Regular 2D movies on a virtual theater screen
answers.Q4: Yes, both devices are on the same WiFi network
answers.Q5: Option A - Movies stored on laptop hard drive

identified_gaps: Unclear what 'ROG Strix 16' role is (streaming source? content storage? display rendering?)
VR goggle model/type not specified (Cardboard-style? Standalone VR? PC VR adapter?)
Connection method between devices unclear (wireless streaming? USB? HDMI adapter?)
Movie source/format not specified (local files? streaming services? 3D/VR content?)
Desired VR experience unclear (side-by-side 3D? 360° video? virtual cinema screen?)
Android phone model/capabilities unknown (affects app compatibility and performance)
Whether user wants to USE the laptop screen content in VR or just store/serve movies
assumptions_made: ROG Strix 16 is likely an ASUS gaming laptop serving as content source
VR goggle is likely a phone-holder style headset (Google Cardboard/similar)
User wants to watch regular movies in a virtual theater environment
Wireless streaming is preferred over wired solutions
analysis.reasoning: This task has multiple valid technical implementations depending on the hardware setup and desired outcome. The relationship between the laptop, phone, and VR headset is ambiguous - it could mean streaming from laptop to phone, mirroring laptop display, or simply using the phone independently with movies transferred from laptop. The VR goggle type dramatically changes the solution approach. These are CRITICAL gaps that would lead to wrong solution if assumed incorrectly.

assumptions: ROG Strix 16 is likely an ASUS gaming laptop serving as content source
VR goggle is likely a phone-holder style headset (Google Cardboard/similar)
User wants to watch regular movies in a virtual theater environment
Wireless streaming is preferred over wired solutions
